title: [K-12] Clinical Knowledge and Socio-Medical Practical Skills Assessment Course for Hospital Pharmacists

context.prior_knowledge: Basic pharmaceutical knowledge, foundational patient care concepts, and understanding of medical ethics and social responsibility.
context.additional_context: Learners assuming roles as pre-service or in-service teachers acquire methods to evaluate clinical competencies of hospital pharmacists in a PBL-based simulation environment. Emphasizes building collaborative relationships with diverse stakeholders (patients, families, medical staff) within healthcare systems and explores educational approaches to address health inequities.

learning_goals: Learners can analyze ten patient cases by body system (cardiovascular, respiratory, nervous, etc.) within one week and write three clinical decisions (diagnosis, treatment plan, prognosis evaluation) for each case according to rubric standards (80% accuracy, 70% evidence presentation). They must also propose treatment plans considering healthcare systems and patient rights.

Learners can enhance their data interpretation skills to establish medication use evaluation and monitoring plans. They develop monitoring strategies that consider drug accessibility from the perspectives of medical resources and social equity.

Learners can propose patient-tailored treatment plans through evidence-based clinical assessments. They apply communication strategies that reflect cultural backgrounds and socioeconomic factors during treatment.
difficulty: Easy - Simple structure with minimal constraints
